During taxi, an aircraft just ahead was cleared to take-off and the reported wind was 27020 KT. What observations should the flight crew raise, given this updated wind?
feedback: The aircraft performance should be re-calculated prior to take-off because there is now a tailwind of approximately 13 KT

question:
(For this question use Performance Manual MRJT 1 Figure 4.24)
With regard to the drift down performance of the twin jet aeroplane, why does the curve representing 35 000 kg gross mass in the chart for drift down net profiles start at approximately 3 minutes at FL370?
feedback: Because at this mass it takes about 3 minutes to decelerate to the optimum speed for drift down at the original cruising level.

question: Consider standard atmosphere conditions and no loss of performance due to altitude. An aircraft is climbing through FL260 at a constant CAS of 300 kt. The current rate of climb is 2000 ft/min and Mach is 0.76. The pilot decides to switch to a climb with constant Mach 0.76. How will the rate of climb and TAS behave?
feedback: TAS decreases, rate of climb increases

question: in a multi engine aeroplane the critical engine is
feedback: The engine which causes the largest yawing moment upon engine failure

question: For a turboprop powered aeroplane, a 2200 m long runway at the destination aerodrome is expected to be "wet". The "dry runway" landing distance, should not exceed:
What is gross performance?
feedback: Calculated performance with no safety factor

question: Which of the following statements with regard to the optimum cruise altitude (best fuel mileage) is correct?
feedback: An aeroplane sometimes flies above the optimum cruise altitude, because ATC normally does not allow to fly continuously at the optimum cruise altitude.

question: At a higher gross mass on a piston-engined aeroplane, in order to maintain a given angle of attack, configuration and altitude:
feedback: the airspeed must be increased and the drag will also increase

question: What happens to jet endurance with altitude?
feedback: Endurance is maximum at a high levels, low OAT, and design RPM

question: Some wind limitations may apply in case of contaminated runways. Those limitations are to be found in ......
feedback: Part B of the Operations Manual

question: What is the advantage of balancing V1, even in the event of a climb limited take-off?
feedback: The safety margin with respect to the runway length is greatest.

Which data can be extracted from the Buffet Onset Boundary Chart?
feedback: The values of the Mach number at which low speed and Mach buffet occur at various masses and altitudes.

question: A head wind will:
feedback: increase the climb flight path angle.

question: If the field length limited take off mass has been calculated using a Balanced Field Length technique, the use of any additional clearway in take off performance calculations may allow
feedback: a greater field length limited take off mass but with a lower V1

question: Long range cruise is selected as
feedback: the higher speed to achieve 99% of maximum specific range in zero wind.

question:

Mass: 4300 lbHeadwind: 25 ktTemperature: 28°CPressure Altitude: 3000 ft
Find the approximate all engine rate of climb (ROC) and the single engine rate of climb.
feedback: All engine ROC 1700 ft/min, single engine rate of climb 335 ft/min

question: Considering a turbine powered aircraft (certificated under CS 25), when passing 35 feet at the end of the take-off distance, the speed should not be less than
The thrust of a jet engine at constant RPM
feedback: increases in proportion to the airspeed.

question: (For this Question use Performance Manual SEP1 Fig. 2.2) With regard to the take off performance chart for the single engine aeroplane determine the take off distance over a 50 ft obstacle height.  Given : O.A.T : 30°C Pressure Altitude: 1000 ft Aeroplane Mass: 2950 lbs Tailwind component: 5 kt Flaps: Approach setting Runway: Short, wet grass, firm subsoil Correction factor: 1.25 (for runway conditions)
Regarding take-off, the take-off decision speed V1:
feedback: is the airspeed on the ground at which the pilot is assumed to have made a decision to continue or discontinue the take-off.

question: If other factors are unchanged, the fuel mileage (nautical miles per kg) is
feedback: lower with a forward centre of gravity position.

question: On a dry runway the accelerate stop distance is increased

Which of the following statements are correct or incorrect?
1) In order to achieve a sufficient level of safety, the weight of a dispatched aeroplane may be limited2) Measured performance is the performance achieved by the manufacturer under test conditions for certification
If the aerodrome pressure altitude increases it will:
If the level-off altitude is below the obstacle clearance altitude during a drift down procedure
feedback: fuel jettisoning should be started at the beginning of drift down.

question: Two identical aeroplanes at different masses are descending at zero wind and zero thrust. Which of the following statements correctly describes their descent characteristics ?
feedback: At a given angle of attack, both the vertical and the forward speed are greater for the heavier aeroplane.

question: Considering VR, Which statement is correct?
feedback: VR is the speed at which rotation should be initiated.

question: Which of the following speed schedules, applicable to the same aeroplane, represents the highest cost index?
feedback: Climb 340 KT/M 0.80, Cruise M 0.80, Descent M 0.80/340 KT

question:
A single-engined piston aeroplane is flying at an altitude of 5000 ft with a constant tailwind component of 15 kt. Given the following information, if the engine fails at this altitude, what should be the expected net glide distance over ground with an elevation of 250 ft?
L/D: 9.1:1TAS: 120 kt1 NM = 6080 ftstill air distance = (height difference / net gradient) x 100. Ground distance = Still Air Distance x (GS/TAS)
An increase in atmospheric pressure has, among other things, the following consequences on take-off performance:
feedback: a reduced take-off distance and improved initial climb performance

question: Which speed represents the maximum endurance speed for a propeller driven aeroplane?

The approach climb requirement has been established to ensure:
feedback: minimum climb gradient in case of a go-around with one engine inoperative.

question: For which hydroplaning speed would you use a factor of 9, used in the following formula: (9 x √ tyre pressure)?
How is V2 affected if T/O flaps 20° is chosen instead of T/O flaps 10°?
feedback: V2 decreases if not restricted by VMCA.

feedback: an increased landing distance and better go-around performance

question: A pilot will commence a drift down procedure after encountering an engine failure ......
feedback: when cruising above the operating altitude for one engine inoperative
